location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: Letter No. 973 of 1858, Henry Lacon Anderson, Secretary to Government, Political Department, Bombay, to Captain Felix Jones, Political Resident, Persian Gulf.

physicalDescription.extent: Foliation: This item has a foliation sequence of a small number in the top right hand corner of each folio.

mods.abstract: Received at Bushire by the "Tigris", 26 July 1858. Replied to 29 July 1858. A memorandum sent (23 April 1858) by Henry Lacon Anderson from Bombay Castle requiring a report in connection with correspondence with Sultan bin Suggar bin Khalid of Ras al-Khaimah.Letter explains that the claim that the Sheekeyheen tribe [Sharqiyin] attacked the town of Dibba is 'wholly without foundation'. Jones contends that the motive for this claim is to enlist sympathy from the Government of India to allow Sultan bin Suggar to be allowed to march against the Sheekeyheen and subject them to his rule and divert them from their allegiance to H.H. the Imam of Muscat. The letter explains that in January 1859 the Resident learnt that Sultan bin Suggar was contemplating a naval expedition against Aboothabee [Abu Dhabi] and interdicted a naval movement whilst also taking measures against the Sheekeyeen to restore property to the Joasmee (Qasimi).
